greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Greatest number having exactly n representations as ab+ac+bc with 0 < a < b < c.
comment: Numbers up to 250,000 were checked. Note that the Mathematica program computes A094376, A094377 and A094378, but outputs only this sequence.
example: a(1) = 193 because 193 is the largest number with a unique representation: (a,b,c) = (4,7,15).
mathematica: cntMax=10; nSol=Table[{0, 0, 0}, {cntMax+1}]; Do[lim=Ceiling[(n-2)/3]; cnt=0; Do[If[n>a*b && Mod[n-a*b, a+b]==0 && Quotient[n-a*b, a+b]>b, cnt++; If[cnt>cntMax, Break[]]], {a, 1, lim-1}, {b, a+1, lim}]; If[cnt<=cntMax, If[nSol[[cnt+1, 1]]==0, nSol[[cnt+1, 1]]=n]; nSol[[cnt+1, 2]]=n; nSol[[cnt+1, 3]]++;], {n, 10000}]; Table[nSol[[i, 2]], {i, cntMax+1}]
xref: Cf. A000926 (n having no representations), A093669 (n having one representation), A094376, A094378.
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Apr 28 2004
ext: More terms (using limit 10^6) from _Joerg Arndt_, Oct 01 2017
